6.23.text:
So let's talk about the tactics of searching
for a job today.

12.43.text:
Some of the tactics are quite different, but
some of the principles are absolutely timeless.

18.62.text: Some of the tactics that are different: LinkedIn.

20.86.text:
LinkedIn is an essential resource for potential
employees and employers.

26.79.text:
It is the de facto global standard for 400
million people in business, part of the reason

33.26.text:
why Microsoft paid $26.2 billion for the global
LinkedIn network.

38.98.text:
But LinkedIn is a really essential thing to
do and filling in and completing a good LinkedIn

48.36.text:
You want to have a really good professional
but personable picture on it because pictures

53.49.text: are more valuable than all the words.

56.42.text:
And then you want to have the equivalent of
a top-level resume in all of your affiliations,

65.02.text: So the LinkedIn profile is key.

67.68.text:
Most likely that's going to be how you get
a job, but when you're in a job conversation

72.58.text:
employers will refer automatically to your
LinkedIn profile so that's really important.

79.39.text:
Before you do a LinkedIn profile it's important
to develop a resume.

83.23.text:
Coming out of college you generally want to
have your resume on one page.

88.89.text:
All the resume basics, there's millions of
things written about resumes, but I will tell

92.57.text:
you one thing, I probably evaluated 20,000
resumes over the last 25 years.

100.54.text:
They look at your name and the mindset is
do I know her or him or not and where are

109.70.text:
And then they quickly look to the bottom of
the page and they look at the personal things.

114.50.text:
And this is where it's really in your power
to differentiate yourself.

118.84.text:
You don't want to say capable at Microsoft
Word and Excel and PowerPoint, the Adobe suite

125.10.text:
Photoshop things, that's fine but that's the
place where you want to say completed the

130.69.text:
world triathlon championship or hiked Machu
Picchu or enjoy cooking and specialize in

142.94.text:
Traveled to whatever, very specific things,
member of the League of Women Voters, if you're

150.43.text:
It creates a little bit of a question that's
a real entrée into the conversation.

157.20.text:
And employers are looking to start a conversation
to say you had three holes in one in golf,

165.86.text: And it's on the bottom of your resume.

170.24.text:
And then the basics: what the company or the
organization or the education is, the year,

176.92.text: a couple of the quantifiable basics, internships.

180.72.text:
And it's okay, especially if you're coming
out of college, to be totally real.

185.83.text:
You mowed lawns for the summer or you bussed
in a restaurant.

192.87.text:
All of those things, which is actually someone
in their 20s you might think oh God I didn't

198.74.text:
learn anything, I didn't do anything, but
employers are looking for those real life

203.08.text:
skills to show work ethic and initiative and
they respected that.

207.30.text:
If you're a camp counselor that's fine too,
but talk about what the experience you gained

213.22.text:
being responsible for a bunk of seven-year-old
girls.

215.71.text:
Anyway, it's okay to be yourself and put that
in the kind of context.

222.56.text:
After the resume it's easier to create your
LinkedIn profile from that.

228.49.text:
It used to be that resumes were sent with
cover letters through the mail.

234.38.text:
They would get opened or not and they would
get filed.

237.64.text:
It's important to know that most of resumes
certainly will be read as a first time, if

243.29.text:
they're read at all they'll be opened most
likely on a mobile device.

246.89.text: So the layout is really important.

248.55.text:
And if you're writing to an HR leader, human
resources later, maybe they'll be reading

255.83.text:
it in their office, but they'll be transmitted
electronically.

260.78.text:
So the principles of a cover letter are a
transmittal email.

264.39.text:
And an email is not a text but an email is
not a formal letter either so it's somewhere

271.78.text:
It's got to be professional, make sure to
have a no grammatical errors in your resume

283.63.text:
But here's the thing, over two thirds of jobs
are gotten through referrals; they're not

291.14.text: gotten by applying cold to an organization.

295.33.text:
And it's really frustrating for people, I
know this, to like look at an employment site;

302.80.text:
go into the jobs listings about us and it
says submit your application or submit your

310.28.text:
resume or LinkedIn profile and a cover letter
and you do that.

315.06.text:
And it feels like you're putting your personal
materials into a black hole.

321.84.text:
Many great companies find a way to have the
systems to get back to you, but most don't.

327.70.text: It's just hard because they get too many inbounds.

331.48.text:
But here's the thing, most positions are filled
before they ever go to be listings and sometimes

338.34.text:
companies feel the need or for legal reasons
that they have to list of them.

342.89.text:
Two thirds of the jobs are gotten through
referrals.

346.00.text:
So with that in mind, and having done your
basics of a good LinkedIn profile and a resume,

351.57.text: here's the way to activate that.

353.85.text:
And this is a timeless principal about job
searching at the entry level all the way up

360.90.text:
It's recommendations by your friends or your
friends of friends.

365.78.text:
And I often get asked what is the single best
piece of job search advice I have?

372.90.text:
And here's what I say: have a crisp answer
to the question so what do you want to do?

382.21.text:
Especially people coming out of college, they're
sometimes surprised by that question and they're

386.64.text: - like the worst answer is I don't know.

390.65.text: The second worst answer is I'll do anything.

393.27.text: You want to be able to help people help you.

398.06.text:
And so you want to have a one sentence answer
to that question of what you want to do that

403.19.text:
makes sense and give someone enough ammunition
so that when they hear that there's an opening

411.19.text:
at the American red cross it's like oh I just
met this really talented young woman who's

416.34.text:
coming out of John's Hopkins University who
is dedicated to helping disaster relief and

423.00.text: she wants to work at the American Red Cross.

426.52.text:
Maybe it's your aunt who you mention that
to at the Father's Day picnic.

432.44.text: You never know where it's going to come from.

434.41.text:
So I like to think that it's like planting
seeds on the wind and sometimes they'll land

442.93.text: So had your one sentence answer.

445.22.text:
And anything is fine, but you really need
to say I've always loved the financial markets;

450.47.text:
I want to get an entry-level position on Wall
Street.

453.49.text:
I'm interested in government; I majored in
political science and I want to break in with

459.93.text:
I'm really passionate about protecting the
environment so I want to find a not for profit

471.43.text:
I'm looking for a company that is really focused
on empowering women.

478.28.text:
Whatever it is have the answer to that and
then say that to as many people as you can

485.46.text: and you'll be shocked at when it comes from.

488.45.text:
And this is where it pays to mention that
to your professors, to your parents, to the

493.55.text:
friends of your parents and to your friends
and most of this will come back.

498.93.text:
And then your LinkedIn profile and your resume
will get kicked in.

503.12.text:
But unless you give someone the tool to say
I'm looking to break into online video production,

509.86.text: nobody will come back and ask you that.

512.15.text:
So anyway, that's my single best piece of
job search advice.
